readme.html:
Torchslit (Vulpes)

iOS "Bulb + Torch" Camera for Long-Exposure Photography

What is it?

Torchslit is a camera app that lets you shoot true-feeling bulb-style long exposures on iPhone while precisely scripting the iPhone's rear LED (torch) as a timed light source—tap-to-burst, scheduled bursts, and repeatable "light scripts" you can replay.

Why?

iPhone's stock camera is missing what long-exposure people actually want:

  • Bulb control: "start exposure… stop exposure" (not a fixed shutter time)
  • Light control: timed bursts of light during the exposure (for light painting, selective illumination)
  • Repeatability: save a lighting pattern and reproduce it

Core Concept

Two engines running together:

  1. Bulb Capture Engine — Captures continuous frames and accumulates them into a single long-exposure image
  2. Light Script Engine — Controls the LED: burst for X seconds, follow a timed sequence, repeat at intervals, or live tap/hold

Project Structure

Torchslit/
├── Sources/
│   ├── App/
│   │   └── TorchslitApp.swift       # App entry point
│   ├── Views/
│   │   ├── ContentView.swift        # Main camera UI
│   │   ├── CameraPreviewView.swift  # Camera preview layer
│   │   └── SettingsView.swift       # Settings sheet
│   ├── Engines/
│   │   ├── CameraManager.swift      # Central state manager
│   │   ├── BulbCaptureEngine.swift  # Frame accumulation (Metal)
│   │   └── LightScriptEngine.swift  # Torch control + timing
│   ├── Models/
│   │   ├── LightScript.swift        # Replayable lighting patterns
│   │   └── CaptureRecipe.swift      # Capture metadata
│   └── Shaders/
│       └── Accumulation.metal       # GPU blend modes
├── Resources/
└── Info.plist

MVP Features

  • Bulb start/stop capture
  • Manual burst (tap to fire torch)
  • Duration selector (0.25s - 5s)
  • Intensity slider
  • Interval burst mode
  • Three blend modes (Max, Additive, Average)
  • Thermal state monitoring
  • Save to Photos with metadata
  • Recipe sidecar export

V1 Features (Later)

  • Light Script editor UI
  • Script presets library
  • Apple Watch remote
  • Live touch mode (hold = torch on)
  • Dark frame subtraction
  • RAW/DNG export

Building

  1. Open in Xcode 15+
  2. Set your development team
  3. Build and run on device (torch requires real hardware)

Technical Notes

Frame Accumulation

Uses Metal compute shaders for real-time blending:

  • Max: Brightest pixel wins (light trails, star trails)
  • Additive: Pixels add together (classic long exposure)
  • Average: Running average (water smoothing, traffic)

Torch Control

Uses AVCaptureDevice.setTorchModeOn(level:) with safety guards:

  • Thermal state monitoring
  • Consecutive burst limits
  • Cooldown periods

Timing

Uses monotonic clock for consistent timestamps across:

  • Shot start/end
  • Frame ingestion
  • Torch events

License

MIT
readme.raw:
# Torchslit (Vulpes)

iOS "Bulb + Torch" Camera for Long-Exposure Photography

## What is it?

Torchslit is a camera app that lets you shoot true-feeling bulb-style long exposures on iPhone while precisely scripting the iPhone's rear LED (torch) as a timed light source—tap-to-burst, scheduled bursts, and repeatable "light scripts" you can replay.

## Why?

iPhone's stock camera is missing what long-exposure people actually want:

- **Bulb control**: "start exposure… stop exposure" (not a fixed shutter time)
- **Light control**: timed bursts of light during the exposure (for light painting, selective illumination)
- **Repeatability**: save a lighting pattern and reproduce it

## Core Concept

Two engines running together:

1. **Bulb Capture Engine** — Captures continuous frames and accumulates them into a single long-exposure image
2. **Light Script Engine** — Controls the LED: burst for X seconds, follow a timed sequence, repeat at intervals, or live tap/hold

## Project Structure

```
Torchslit/
├── Sources/
│   ├── App/
│   │   └── TorchslitApp.swift       # App entry point
│   ├── Views/
│   │   ├── ContentView.swift        # Main camera UI
│   │   ├── CameraPreviewView.swift  # Camera preview layer
│   │   └── SettingsView.swift       # Settings sheet
│   ├── Engines/
│   │   ├── CameraManager.swift      # Central state manager
│   │   ├── BulbCaptureEngine.swift  # Frame accumulation (Metal)
│   │   └── LightScriptEngine.swift  # Torch control + timing
│   ├── Models/
│   │   ├── LightScript.swift        # Replayable lighting patterns
│   │   └── CaptureRecipe.swift      # Capture metadata
│   └── Shaders/
│       └── Accumulation.metal       # GPU blend modes
├── Resources/
└── Info.plist
```

## MVP Features

- [x] Bulb start/stop capture
- [x] Manual burst (tap to fire torch)
- [x] Duration selector (0.25s - 5s)
- [x] Intensity slider
- [x] Interval burst mode
- [x] Three blend modes (Max, Additive, Average)
- [x] Thermal state monitoring
- [ ] Save to Photos with metadata
- [ ] Recipe sidecar export

## V1 Features (Later)

- [ ] Light Script editor UI
- [ ] Script presets library
- [ ] Apple Watch remote
- [ ] Live touch mode (hold = torch on)
- [ ] Dark frame subtraction
- [ ] RAW/DNG export

## Building

1. Open in Xcode 15+
2. Set your development team
3. Build and run on device (torch requires real hardware)

## Technical Notes

### Frame Accumulation

Uses Metal compute shaders for real-time blending:
- **Max**: Brightest pixel wins (light trails, star trails)
- **Additive**: Pixels add together (classic long exposure)
- **Average**: Running average (water smoothing, traffic)

### Torch Control

Uses `AVCaptureDevice.setTorchModeOn(level:)` with safety guards:
- Thermal state monitoring
- Consecutive burst limits
- Cooldown periods

### Timing

Uses monotonic clock for consistent timestamps across:
- Shot start/end
- Frame ingestion
- Torch events

## License

MIT
